article:
'Hazem Daouk' is a financial economist, known for his work on securities
regulation, especially insider trading, earnings management and short selling.
He is the Peter J. & Stephanie J. Nolan Associate Professor in the Charles H.
Dyson School of Applied Economics and Management at Cornell University. His
articles have been cited over 2000 times (Google Scholar). [http://scholar.-
google.com/scholar?q=%22hazem+daouk%22&hl=en&btnG=Search&as_sdt=1%2C5&as_sdtp=on
Articles on Google Scholar]. Retrieved 11 February 2012. Note: Authors of
financial economics articles are listed in alphabetical order.

In 1998, his research uncovered the rampant insider trading on the Mexican Stock
Exchange. [http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=146735 âWhen an
event is not an event: The curious case of an emerging marketâ] (with U.
Bhattacharya, B. Jorgenson, and C. Kehr), [[Journal of Financial Economics]],
2000, '55', 69-101. [http://www.chicagotribune.com/business/columnists/chi-
barnhart-bio,0,214285.story Barnhart, Bill] (March 12, 1998). âInside Mexicoâ.
[[Chicago Tribune]], p. 6. Henderson, Barry (February 8, 1999).
âCorruption? Caramba! Academics find widespread insider trading in Mexicoâ.
[[Barron's (newspaper)|Barronâs]], p. 22-23. This led to many questions
about the value and the enforceability of insider trading laws. The study won
the Best Academic Paper Award offered by the International Investment Forum at
the University of Chicago.

In later research, Daouk conducted a comprehensive survey of insider trading
laws and prosecution in about a hundred countries that have a stock market. He
then showed that countries that enforce insider trading laws reduce the cost of
financing of companies by many percentage points. This is because outside
investors no longer require to be compensated for the money they lose from
trading with better-informed insiders. On the other hand, having the law without
enforcing it, does not do anything. [http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=249708 âThe
world price of insider tradingâ] (with U. Bhattacharya), Journal of Finance,
2002, '57', 75-108. Reprinted in Claessens S. and
[http://www.imf.org/external/np/cv/AuthorCV.aspx?AuthID=132 L. Laeven] (ed),
2006, [http://books.google.com/books?id=Nv7KOdT3CbAC&hl=fr&source=gbs_book_othe-
r_versions âA reader in international corporate financeâ], World Bank, Herndon,
VA, USA. [http://www.economist.com/node/328509 âThe cost of inequityâ]
(January 22, 2000). [[The Economist]]. Beard, Alison (April 12, 2001)
âFew countries enforcing insider trading lawsâ. [[Financial
Times]]. [http://www.jaschahoffman.com/about/resume/ Hoffman, Jascha]
(March 3, 2004) âInsider trading: A good thing?â [[The Boston Globe|Boston
Globe]]. Ramsay, Ian (August 8, 2005)
[http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2005/08/07/1123353208631.html?oneclick=true
âASICâs uphill fight to keep âem honestâ]. [[The Age]]. This research was
nominated for the Smith Breeden Prize for Best Paper in the [[Journal of
Finance]] for the year 2002.

A little before the Enron scandal, Daouk was investigating whether informational
risk associated with accounting earnings quality impacts stock markets around
the world (he analyzed financial statements from 34 countries for the period 1985-
1998). He found that accounting manipulation in a country, increases
significantly the cost of financing of companies and reduces liquidity. [http://aaajournals.org/doi/abs/10.2308/accr.2003.78.3.641 âThe
world price of earnings opacityâ] (with U. Bhattacharya and M. Welker), [[The
Accounting Review|Accounting Review]], 2003, '78', 641-
678. [http://www.gogomag.com/talkingheads/bios/females/Margaret_Poppe-
r.php Popper, Margaret] (July 22, 2002)
[http://www.businessweek.com/magazine/content/02_29/c3792032.htm#B3792035
"Economic trends: America the transparent"]. [[Bloomberg
Businessweek]]. [http://www.moneymediakit.com/bios/MON_Weisser.html
Weisser, Cybele] (September 2002) "Word on the street: Homebound". [[Money
(magazine)|Money]], p. 37-38.

Daouk is also known for his research that documents short selling laws and
practice in about a hundred stock markets in the world. He shows that when short
selling is possible, stock prices are less volatile and there is greater
liquidity. However, he does not oppose the temporary restrictions on short
selling that were enacted in different countries in reaction to the financial
crisis. [http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=687562 âMarket-
wide short-selling restrictionsâ] (with A. Charoenrook), Cornell University
working paper, 2005. [http://uk.linkedin.com/in/jmbeck Beck, John]
(October 3, 2011) âMarket controls: Does intervention work?â [[The Banker]],
cover story.
